name: Ohio State University - Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center
desc: The Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center is an Office of Research center at The Ohio State University focused on maintaining research excellence and supporting public engagement in polar and climate studies at Ohio State.

name: Canal Winchester Public Service
desc: Public Service Department for the city of Canal Winchester, Ohio.

name: Citizens Climate Lobby Columbus
desc: The Citizens Climate Lobby primarily works on federal legislation to efficiently and effectively reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Citizens Climate Lobby is a climate change organization that exists to create the political will for a livable world by enabling individual breakthroughs in the exercise of personal and political power. (Contact: Donny Murray, CCLColumbusChapter@gmail.com).

name: City of Bexley Sustainability
desc: In the City of Bexley, the Sustainability Department was created in 2022 to implement the City's sustainability goals, which fall under the City's mission to "Protect, preserve, and enhance Bexley's natural and developed environment." Currently, the department is tasked with carrying out the Cities Race to Zero Program, supporting the Environmental Sustainability Advisory Committee in their implementation of the Zero Waste Goal, and preparing future programs including Universal Recycling, restaurant composting, and energy aggregation. (Contact: Elizabeth Ellman, eellman@bexley.org)

name: City of Columbus - Greenspot
desc: Columbus GreenSpot inspires, educates, and recognizes households, businesses, nonprofits, and neighborhoods that adopt sustainable practices. Members choose from more than 40 actions they can take to live and operate more sustainably. It is free to join and be a member. Each member gets their own eDashboard where they can track their successes. More than 23,000 members and growing each day. (Contact: David R. Celebrezze, DRCelebrezze@columbus.gov).

name: City of Columbus - LinkUS
desc: LinkUS is a collaborative initiative co-sponsored by the City of Columbus, Central Ohio Transit Authority, the Mid-Ohio Regional Planning Commission, and the Franklin County Board of Commissioners. LinkUS seeks to provide a complete mobility system along key regional corridors, including high capacity and advanced rapid transit, technology solutions, bicycle and pedestrian improvements, and land use changes. The initiative is a response to the challenges facing a growing region, including managing traffic congestion, ensuring equitable access to jobs and housing, promoting economic vitality, and improved sustainability. It builds on numerous previous regional planning efforts, including COTA’s NextGen plan and the MORPC Insight 2050 Corridor Concepts study. Ongoing collaboration with other growth management efforts will be essential to its success. (Contacts: Rory McGuiness, ROMcGuiness@columbus.gov; Justin Goodwin, JMGoodwin@columbus.gov).

name: City of Columbus - Public Health
desc: City of Columbus Public Health is the local public health department for the City of Columbus and they are responsible for enforcing all Ohio codes and laws related to public health, including food safety water safety those types of things. The mission of Columbus Public Health is to protect health and improve lives in our community. The department is charged with assuring conditions in which people can be healthy. Columbus Public Health is made up of a range of programs providing clinical, environmental, health promotion, and population-based services.

name: Clean Fuels Ohio
desc: Clean Fuels Ohio improves air quality and health, reduces environmental pollution, and strengthens Ohio's economy by increasing the use of cleaner, domestic fuels and energy-saving vehicles. (Contact: Nicholas Strata, nstrata@cleanfuelsohio.org).

name: Columbus and Franklin County Metroparks
desc: Columbus and Franklin County Metro Parks (Metro Parks) is a public agency serving the citizens of Central Ohio by providing a regional system of clean, safe, natural area parks. Metro Parks features 20 outstanding natural area parks with more than 230 miles of trails and over 28,400 acres of land in seven Central Ohio counties.

name: Columbus Community Bill of Rights
desc: Columbus Communtiy Bill of Rights is a non-profit organization focused on protecting Columbus water, soil, and air from oil and gas waste. Our organization has organized four campaigns for a Community Bill of Rights to protect the water of the Columbus area from frack waste injection wells in our watershed.

name: Denison University
desc: A major role of Denison University, located in Granville, is educating and informing on issues of sustainability, on multiple levels, including with direct stakeholders and students.

name: Dublin City Government
desc: The City Government of Dublin works on projects related to the provision of sustainable resources within their community. Dublin is a city of nearly 50,000 residents located just northwest of Columbus, Ohio. It offers residents and corporate citizens responsive services, attractive housing options, superior public education, direct regional highway access, abundant park space, thoughtful and strategic planning, innovative ideas and technology and a dynamic community life. Dublin is ranked the number one small city in Ohio and is consistently named one of the safest cities in the nation. It is home to more than 20 corporate headquarters, an entrepreneurial center, 4,300+ businesses, world-class events and the urban, walkable Bridge Street District. (Contact: egoliver@dublin.oh.us).

name: Environmental Education Council of Ohio
desc: At EECO (Environmental Education Council of Ohio), the mission is to be a leader in the promotion and facilitation of Environmental Education (EE), and to nurture knowledge, attitudes and behaviors. (Contact: Brenda Metcalf, director@eeco-online.org).

name: Environmental Law and Policy Center
desc: With their office in Columbus, ELPC (Environmental Law and Policy Center) is well-positioned to advance a transition towards a cleaner renewable energy future and smart energy efficiency. They advocate with regulators, legislators, and business leaders across the Buckeye state. (Contact: Tyler Barron tbarron@elpc.org).

name: Franklin County Public Health
desc: Franklin County Public Health is a local health department serving 41 jurisdictions in Franklin County, Ohio. Our mission is to improve the health of our communities by preventing disease, promoting healthy living, and protecting against public health threats through education, policies, programs, and partnerships. (Contact: Jennie McAdams, JennieMcAdams@franklincountyohio.gov).

name: Franklin Park Conservatory and Botanical Gardens
desc: Inspired by horticulture, Franklin Park Conservatory and Botanical Gardens elevates quality of life and connects the community through educational, cultural and social experiences. We are a public garden and and so plants are first and foremost for us because that's what we do: we try to educate about all things related to plants. (Contact: Jenny Pope, Director of Community Outreach and Education, jpope@fpconservatory.org).

name: Franklin Soil and Water Conservation District
desc: Franklin Soil and Water Conservation District's mission is to promote responsible land use decisions for the conservation, protection and improvement of soil and water resources by providing information assistance through effective partnering, technical guidance and education. (Contact: Jennifer Fish, jfish@franklinswcd.org).

name: Franklinton Farms
desc: Franklinton Farms, or “The Farms”, is a non-profit organization located in Columbus, Ohio. The Farms was founded in 2007 by a group of neighborhood residents committed to environmental sustainability and social justice.

name: Friends of Alum Creek and Tributaries
desc: The goal of Friends of Alum Creek and Tributaries is to preserve, protect, and educate people regarding the watershed within central Ohio in the lower Alum Creek watershed.

name: Friends of Columbus Metroparks
desc: Friends of the Columbus Metroparks is the nonprofit partner to CFCMP, who advocates for the metroparks, aims to enhance the metroparks experience, educate people about the metroparks, all to ensure that the metroparks cotinue to thrive. (Contact: Melissa Meyer, mameyer@metroparks.net).

name: Friends of Lower Olentangy Watershed
desc: The Friends of the Lower Olentangy Watershed's mission is to keep the Olentangy River and its tributaries clean and safe for all to enjoy, through public education, volunteer activities, and coordination with local decision-makers.  FLOW is currently implementing our Greenspace Improvement Plan by targeting action at our potential high quality tier parcels using multiple best management practices like invasive species removal, reforesting floodplains and tributary corridors, and planting, seeding or weeding pollinator gardens along our Pollinator Pathway.  Our Greenspace project will benefit the entire 157 square mile Lower Olentangy watershed as a demonstration of what can be done to improve the quality for both humans and wildlife for other watersheds. (Contact: Laura Fay, lfay2311@gmail.com).

name: Gahanna Parks and Recreation
desc: The Parks and Recreation Department for the City of Gahanna. They prioritize preserving recreation opportunities for their constituents, including public lands, waterways, and national fields.

name: Grange Insurance Audubon Center
desc: Grange Insurance Audubon Center is a hub of resources for the general public on environmental topics, and is an example of ecological restoration within Columbus. (Contact: David Helm, david.helm@audubon.org).

name: Green Bexley
desc: Green Bexley is an official committee of the City of Bexley that works to assist the city accomplishing its zero waste objective before or by 2040. It does so by educating, engaging, advocating, advising, and liaising, as well as by working with the city on environmental sustainability and other ways.

name: Green Columbus
desc: Through forums and platforms, Green Columbus aims to provide opportunities around sustainability for as many groups and people as possible.

name: Green Gahanna
desc: Green Gahanna provides a place for networking of friendly Gahanna outdoor enthusiasts, interested in sustainability, gardening, earth care, natural science, and related topics. Green Gahanna is a Facebook group of citizens who share environmental awareness & advocacy opportunities. (Contact: Catherine Hope-Cunningham, chopecunningham@gmail.com).

name: Grove City Public Service
desc: Grove City Public Service provides the critical infrastructure services that the city depends on, including the roadways, pavements, traffic signals and streetlights, water storm sewers, and sanitary sewers. They are responsbile for everything that is green and growing in the city, as well as public facilities and  public fleet vehicles that provide service to the community.

name: Impact Community Action
desc: The role of Impact Community Action is to help people in crisis and find a way to self sufficiency, including through their  weatherization department. They help homeowners save money in their utility bills through weatherization, because it's better for the environment, for their health, and  for people economically.

name: Local Matters
desc: Local Matters leads the effort to ensure that everyone in Central Ohio has the knowledge and skill to make healthful, economic food choices. They work with partners to reinforce infrastructure that connects people to food, no matter their zip code or circumstance. They also advocate for and with our community members who prioritize justice and equality throughout our food system. (Contact: Jessica Williams, jwilliams@local-matters.org).

name: MAD Scientists Associates LLC
desc: MAD provides high-quality wetland and ecological consulting services to clients in the public and private sectors. Our clients include engineering firms, universities, park districts, industries, and municipal governments. Clients have come to rely on MAD for threatened and endangered species/critical habitat surveys, full wetland services (delineation, permitting, mitigation & monitoring), stream characterizations and aquatic studies, botanical surveys, ecological risk assessments, and other specialized ecological services. (Contact: Mark A. Dilley, Chief Scientist, mark@madscientistassociates.net).

name: Mid-Ohio Regional Planning Commision
desc: MORPC is Central Ohio’s regional council for more than 75 members comprised of counties, cities, villages, townships, and regional organizations. We take pride in bringing communities of all sizes and interests together to collaborate on best practices and plan for the future of our growing region. We do this through a variety of programs, services, projects and initiatives – all with the goal of improving the lives of our residents and making Central Ohio stand out on the world stage.

name: Mom's Clean Air Force - Ohio
desc: The role of Mom's Clean Air Force Ohio is to mobilize parents and grandparents around  clean air and climate change impacts through advocacy work and coalition-building.

name: National Wild Turkey Federation - Ohio
desc: NWTF (National Wild Turkey Federation) Ohio and its partners put resources toward improving the most critical habitat for wildlife and to open access to land for hunting. They are committed to improving water quality, forest health, and restoring grasslands.

name: Ohio Bird Conservation Initiative
desc: OBCI is a network of organizations within Ohio and regionally working together to advance bird conservation. OBCI's mission is to ensure the conservation and effective management of birds in Ohio by fostering partnerships among governmental agencies, conservation organizations, businesses, and the public. (Contact: Matthew Shumar, obcicoordinator@gmail.com).

name: Ohio Citizen Action
desc: Ohio Citizen Action organizes and mobilizes people to advocate for public interests. In person, by phone, and online, we engage people in actions that protect public health, improve environmental quality, and benefit consumers. Our campaigns connect Ohioans and build a movement to protect democracy and create a sustainable future.

name: Ohio Department of Transportation - Office of Environmental Services
desc: The Ohio Department of Transportation - Office of Environmental Services is responsible for providing education, training, technical expertise, and procedure development for ODOT to achieve a safe, efficient and environmentally compliant transportation system.​​​  OES achieves its goals through the dedicated work of staff who monitor and implement environmental laws, rules and regulations through ODOT's environmental, design, construction and maintenance programs.

name: Ohio Ecological Food and Farm Association
desc: Founded in 1979, the Ohio Ecological Food and Farm Association (OEFFA) cultivates a future in which sustainable and organic farmers thrive, local food nourishes our communities, and agricultural practices protect and enhance our environment. Specifically, OEFFA's Policy Program advocates for state and federal policies that protect and benefit sustainable agriculture, research and education, and the public's right to know. Working with our members, we give voice to concerned citizens and ecological family farmers who are safeguarding the environment and providing us with healthy and nutritious food choices. (Contact: Lauren Hirtle, lauren@oeffa.org).

name: Ohio Energy Project
desc: Ohio Energy Project (OEP) is a 501c(3) nonprofit organization serving students, teachers, and communities in all things energy education. Through STEM-based, standards-designed programs, OEP empowers the next generation to take charge of their future and lead their peers, families, and communities in energy literacy, environmental sustainability, and conservation. (Contact: Jessica Sarber, jsarber@ohioenergy.org).

name: Ohio Environmental Council
desc: The OEC works for pragmatic solutions to keep Ohio clean and beautiful, and our communities safe. We fight for clean air and water, clean energy, and protected public lands. We hold polluters accountable in court while working with communities and companies that want to invest in a clean, more sustainable direction. For more than 50 years, we have led many of the major environmental policy wins in Ohio. (Contact, Chris Tavenor, Staff Attorney, ctavenor@theoec.org)

name: Ohio Environmental Health Association
desc: The role of OEHA (Ohio Environmental Health Association) is to support registered environmental health specialists to do their job more effectively and more efficiently, resulting in better Community health Community environmental health.

name: Ohio Environmental Protection Agency - Division of Air Pollution Control
desc: The Division of Air Pollution Control in the Ohio EPA is a regulatory organization. The Ohio Environmental Protection Agency is a trusted leader and environmental steward using innovation, quality service and public involvement to ensure a safe and healthy environment for all Ohioans. (Contact: stephanie.habinak@epa.ohio.gov).

name: Ohio Environmental Protection Agency - Division of Drinking and Ground Waters
desc: A State Agency government subdivision, which regulates drinking water that's for public use.

name: Ohio Farm Bureau Federation
desc: Ohio Farm Bureau is a grassroots membership organization that is committed to supporting our farm and food community. Ohio Farm Bureau is a 501(c)(5) independent, non-governmental, private, volunteer-member powered organization. For more than 100 years, we have represented food, fiber, and fuel producers at a local level and on a national scale. Our members are our top priority, and we are tuned into the top agricultural issues affecting their lives.  Mission of the Ohio Farm Bureau - Working together for Ohio farmers to advance agriculture and strengthen our communities.

name: Ohio Forestry Association
desc: OFA is an independent organization, operating not-for-profit and chartered to promote the general welfare of the people and private enterprise of the state of Ohio.  The association supports the management of Ohio's forest resources and improvement of business conditions for the benefits of its members in their endeavors to engage in forestry-related industries and enterprises. (Contact: Jenna Reese, jenna@ohioforest.org).

name: Ohioans for Sustainable Change
desc: Ohioans for Sustainable Change (previously, Ohio Interfaith Power and Light) is built to organize, engage, and center the voices of directly impacted people of diverse beliefs. It is an affiliate of Interfaith Power and Light. We build with faith and community leaders on the issues of climate, racial, economic, and environmental justice and health equity. We use public and popular education, leadership training and development, direct action, and advocacy to create long-term sustainable change.

name: Ohio Invasive Plant Council
desc: The Ohio Invasive Plants Council strives to improve awareness of the threats of invasive plants in Ohio, while bringing together a diverse group of partners including the nursery industry, landowners and managers, acedemic researchers, state and Federal agencies, Master Gardeners, and others interested in invasive plant issues. (Contact: Jennifer Windus, jlwindus@embarqmail.com).

name: Ohio Nature Education
desc: Ohio Nature Education is a private non-profit volunteer organization which provides a home for over forty wild animals that can no longer live in the wild. We incorporate these animals into environmental education programs for people of all ages. Our customers include schools, Scout troops, libraries, garden clubs, senior centers, metro parks, and community centers. Our programs include live education animals and collections of study skins, nests, and other natural materials useful as aids in learning about nature. (Contact: Manon VanSchoyck, mvs@ohionature.org).

name: Ohio Green Industry Association
desc: OGIA (Ohio Green Industry Association) leads, promotes, and facilitates the success and growth of green industry businesses. More than 1,300 members comprise nursery stock growers, garden center operators, landscape contractors, landscape design and grounds maintenance firms, arborists, students enrolled in landscape and horticulture programs in the state and allied suppliers. The association has represented Ohio‚Äôs vital green industry for more than 100 years. (Previously Ohio Nursery and Landscape Association). (Contact: Tracy Schiefferle tracy@ogia.org).

name: Ohio Public Works Commission
desc: The Ohio Public Works Commission is a state agency that works with local communities, providing technical assistance on projects related to the administration of the Clean Ohio Conservation Green Space Program.

name: Ohio Sea Grant
desc: Ohio Sea Grant has worked to protect the environment of Lake Erie and the Great Lakes. With a strong combination of research, education and outreach efforts, as well as partnerships with academia, governmental agencies and the private sector, Ohio Sea Grant works with the Lake Erie community to solve the region’s most important environmental and economic issues. Stone Laboratory, Ohio Sea Grant’s education and outreach facility on Lake Erie, serves scientists from across the Great Lakes region, offering lab facilities, field work equipment, research vessels and housing for researchers studying Lake Erie.

name: Ohio Solar United Neighborhoods
desc: Solar United Neighbors (SUN) is a national 501(c)3 nonprofit with an Ohio affiliate. They represent the needs and interests of solar owners and supporters across the country.

name: Ohio State University - Carbon Management and Sequestration Center
desc: The Carbon Management and Sequestration Center is a research organization at Ohio State University. It is a knowledge program, so they create and distribute knowledge related to the intersection of agriculture and carbon sequestration.

name: Ohio State University - Clean Energy Research Laboratory
desc: The Clean Energy Research Laboratory at Ohio State is a group of professors and graduate students who conduct engineering-related research into clean energy topics. (Contact: Liang-Shih Fan, fan.1@osu.edu).

name: Ohio State University - Center for Urban and Regional Analysis
desc: The role of CURA (Center for Urban and Regional Analysis) at The Ohio State University is supporting evidence based policy related to sustainable and resilient urban design.

name: Ohio State University - College of Food, Agricultural, and Environmental Science
desc: The College of Food, Agriculture, and Environmental Sciences at Ohio State University. There are hundreds of professors and students who study and research a variety of topics related to agriculture and the environment.

name: Ohio State University - Environmental Professionals Network
desc: The Environmental Professionals Network (EPN) is a service of the School of Environment and Natural Resources that connects and grows environmental professionals in-person and online. Participants in the Environmental Professionals Network can access many online services and are linked to thousands of professionals in Ohio and beyond. (Contact: Joe Campbell, campbell.844@osu.edu).

name: Ohio State University - Facilities Operations and Development
desc: The Facilities Operations and Development Office supports The Ohio State University's academic facility needs through design and construction, environmental health and safety, energy services and sustainability, operations, and utilities.

name: Ohio State University - Knowledge Exchange
desc: The mission of the Knowledge Exchange at Ohio State University is to bring together researchers, extension professionals, decision makers, communicators, and the public to share explore and engage with relevant data and CFAES research.

name: Ohio State University - Office of Student Life
desc: The Office of Student Life (Green Buckeyes) at Ohio State University. This office helps students and staff to make responsible, sustainable choices to meet the needs of our community. We provide recommendations for building systems, waste removal and other functions to support energy conservation and sustainability, and to measure the success of these efforts. (Contact, Tom Reeves, Reeves.5@osu.edu)

name: Ohio State University - School of Environment and Natural Resources
desc: The School of Environment and Natural Resources (SENR) at The Ohio State University is a distinct, interdisciplinary academic unit administratively housed within the College of Food, Agricultural, and Environmental Sciences (CFAES). The School of Environment and Natural Resources creates science-based knowledge and fosters environmental sustainability through teaching, research and outreach.

name: Ohio State University - State Climate Office of Ohio
desc: Accessing accurate climate information, education, and interpretation is critical for policy makers and all sectors of Ohio’s economy and will enhance the quality of life, health, food and water security, and economic prosperity of all Ohioans. The State Climate Office of Ohio (SCOO) is a new team based at The Ohio State University (OSU) that connects Ohioans with transformative climate information.

name: Ohio State University - Sustainability Institute
desc: The Sustainability Institute collaborates with academic and operations units across the university to advance sustainability and resilience scholarship and activities. We aim to establish Ohio State as a leader in sustainability research and applications; educate and empower students; accelerate campus sustainability and living lab opportunities; grow resources to support these efforts; and catalyze a culture of sustainability. (Contact: Mike Shelton, shelton.267@osu.edu).

name: Ohio State University - Water Resources Center
desc: The Ohio Water Resources Center (Ohio WRC) is the federally-authorized and state-designated Water Resources Research Institute for the State of Ohio. Our mission is to enable and conduct state-relevant water-related research; foster collaboration among academic investigators, governmental bodies, and water professionals; train the next generation of water scientists; and educate the public on water resources issues in Ohio. With evidence-based scientific information, we form links between water researchers and those who manage and use water. (Contact: Ohio Water Resources Center, ohiowrc@osu.edu).

name: Ohio State University - Wexner Medical Center
desc: Wexner Medical Center is an anchor institution - a public organization that is permanent to Columbus and firmly invested in the success of the community. All of WMC's sustainability efforts align with their Strategic Plan and The Ohio State University’s resource stewardship goals. The progress toward sustainability initiatives at the medical center is extraordinary and this page only captures a small sample of the outstanding work and our successes. (Contact: Lauren Koch, lauren.koch@osumc.edu).

name: Ohio State University OARDC
desc: The mission of The Ohio Agricultural Research And Development Center is to enhance the well-being of the people of Ohio, the nation and world through research on foods, agriculture, family and the environment. OARDC is the name of the Ohio Agricultural Experiment Station and is a state-wide program that supports research at all CFAES OSU locations, including Columbus, Wooster, and all Agricultural Research Stations.

name: Ohio Sustainable Business Council
desc: Ohio Sustainable Business Council facilitates educational and networking events on sustainability. We share our members’ sustainability story and practices. We keep the business community informed of important policies affecting the sustainability of Ohio’s economy.

name: Ohio Water Environment Association
desc: The Ohio Water Environment Association's role is one of educating both our citizens, legislators and regulators, in the role the water environment has in their everyday lives. The Ohio Water Environment Association is a non-profit, wastewater related organization with over 2000 members.

name: Ohio Wesleyan University
desc:
Ohio Wesleyan University is an undergraduate college in Delaware, Ohio with a long history of facilitating student projects focused on the environment, first through its long-standing, interdisciplinary Environmental Studies Program and now through the Department of Environment & Sustainability. The E & S Department is committed to helping undergraduates gain knowledge through vibrant classroom learning and to creating diverse opportunities for students to work with community partners to apply that knowledge and improve regional sustainability. Current projects include work on green infrastructure on campus, building collaborative scientific research projects on the environment across networks of natural areas, training students in technical skills like GIS and remote sensing, and supporting a range of local student internships. 

Contacts: Dr. Nathan Rowley (nrowley@owu.edu, Department Chair), Dr. Laurel Anderson (ljanders@owu.edu), Dr. John Krygier (jbkrygie@owu.edu)

name: Ohio Wildlife Center
desc: The Ohio Wildlife Center is a 5012c3 nonprofit organization with three decades of service in Columbus and Central Ohio that operates the state’s largest, donation supported wildlife hospital as well as a 22 acre education center and campus. Its role in the community is to carry out wildlife rescues and rehabilitation of injured, ill or orphaned animals to return them to natural habitats after recovery. It also carries out conservation education programming that reaches more than 30,000 Ohioans annually.

name: Power a Clean Future Ohio
desc: Power A Clean Future Ohio is a nonpartisan coalition that works with local leaders to develop and implement proven climate solutions. They are committed to reducing carbon emissions throughout Ohio in big and small ways that make sense for each local community. Ohio’s economy, health and future depend on a new approach to clean energy and climate change.

name: Preservation Parks
desc: Preservation Parks is committed to preserving Delaware County’s natural areas, which are home to thousands of native plant and animal species and are special places for people. Park District conservation efforts focus on land acquisition, prairie and wetland restoration, reforestation and invasive species management in an effort to improve wildlife habitat. Walking trails, picnic areas, reservable shelters, natural play areas, nature displays, wildlife blinds, and other features provide a variety of ways for visitors to enjoy the parks. Their educational efforts take us into classrooms in every school system —public and private — in Delaware County, with engaging programs that excite young people.

name: Regional Ohio Action for Resilience
desc: ROAR (Regional Ohio Action for Resilience) functions not so much as a new organization but rather as a catalyst to spur a wide range of people, organizations, non-profits, colleges, towns, cities and communities to create specific, collaborative ventures to address the climate crisis locally, across the central Ohio region. We seek out what is possible, what is already in the works and try to expand those by encouraging cooperative action beyond typical boundaries, all with the aim of enhancing bioregional awareness and deep-level, systemic environmental change. (Contact: thermsen@otterbein.edu). Website: https://roar4climate.org.

name: Rural Action
desc: Rural Action is a community economic development organization for Appalachian communities in Ohio.

name: Shared Power Network
desc: Shared Power Network develops on-site solar energy projects for schools and educationally-focused nonprofit organizations. We partner with these groups to bring solar energy education into the classroom. (Contact: Jake Kuss, jakekuss@sharedpowernetwork.org).

name: Simply Living
desc: Simply Living is a non-profit organization driven by the concept of change or transition to an ecological future.

name: Stratford Ecological Center
desc: The Stratford Ecological Center is dedicated to the education of children and adults in understanding of the relationship between living things and their environment, thereby fostering an appreciation for the land and all life that depends on it. (Contact: Jeff Dickinson, farmscaper@stratfordecologicalcenter.org).

name: Sustainable Columbus
desc: Recognizing the role a healthy environment plays in contributing to Columbus continuing to be America’s Opportunity City, the City of Columbus established the Sustainable Columbus initiative. This initiative, under the leadership of Columbus Mayor Andrew J. Ginther, focuses on optimizing internal city operations and working with external stakeholders from throughout the community to enhance and promote environmentally friendly policies throughout our community.

name: Sustainable Delaware Ohio
desc: Sustainable Delaware is a group of residents focused on promoting environmental, social, and economic sustainability for the Delaware community through awareness, advocacy, and action. To learn more, see https://sustainabledelawareohio.org/. (Contact: Anna Willow, willow.1@osu.edu).

name: Sustainable Grandview
desc: Sustainable Grandview is a community action organization focused on realizing a cleaner healthier more resilient Grandview Heights Ohio. (Contact: Andrew Leber, aleber@gmail.com).

name: Sustainable Worthington
desc: Sustainable Worthington's goal is to find a very local way of trying to make their community as sustainable as possible.

name: SWACO
desc: SWACO (Solid Waste Authority of Central Ohio) is a catalyst to help our community manage our resources in a more effective way. Ultimately, they do so by offering ways to reduce or diverting waste from the landfill.

name: Columbus Foundation - Green Fund
desc: Originally established in 2011 by a committed group of donors, The Columbus Foundation‚ Green Funds seek to support organizations, foster dialogue around conservation issues, and facilitate projects that will make an impact in central Ohio today and in the future. (Contact: Victoria Prokup, vprokup@columbusfoundation.org).

name: The Nature Conservancy - Ohio
desc: From wetlands and rivers to forests and prairies, The Nature Conservancy is a non-profit organization protecting Ohio's most biodiverse places throughout the state. (Contact: Amy Holtshouse, amy.holtshouse@tnc.org).

name: The Wildlife Society - Ohio
desc: The Ohio Wildlife Society is a professional repository of expertise representing the national professional organization at the state level in providing immediate response on policy advocacy or expertise, to the professional community when wildlife needs arise. (Contact: Renee Buck, rbuck@pheasantsforever.org).

name: United States Geological Survey - Ohio
desc: The USGS is the sole science agency for the Department of the Interior. It is sought out by thousands of partners and customers for its natural science expertise and its vast earth and biological data holdings.

name: Unpredictable City
desc: Unpredictable City is an organization that has teamed up with other organizations for environmental and sustainability consulting projects (Contact: Jon-Paul d'Aversa, jpdaversa@UNPREDICTABLE.city)

name: Whitehall Parks and Recreation
desc: Whitehall Parks and Recreation is a city department whose purpose it is to make safe green spaces and recreational opportunities available to the residents of Whitehall.

name: Ohio Youth for Climate Justice
desc: Ohio Youth for Climate Justice is a a youth-led group organizing action or direct actions to address the climate crisis in Ohio.
